text: {"grade": 0, "reasoning": "The criterion requires the response to claim that environmental obligations cannot form the basis of any counterclaim under international law. The candidate answer does not make this claim. Instead, it discusses the admissibility of counterclaims based on domestic environmental law, noting that tribunals might accept such claims if the BIT's applicable law clause incorporates host-state law (citing Burlington/Perenco) or if international law imposes such obligations (citing Urbaser, though noting this is theoretical). The response analyzes the possibility of applying domestic environmental law, it does not assert that environmental obligations *cannot* form the basis of a counterclaim.", "criterion_id": "4039082c-276f-47cd-ad4b-06fd8b91be97"}
